comments:
When I misspell the Instance Class Name of an EData Type in an ecore model, and try to (re)generate the model, I get a very crude error message (dialogbox see attachment) and the following entry in the log. IMHO, this could more user friendly.

eclipse.buildId=I20060922-0010

java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc.

Created an attachment (id=52588)
dialogbox with error message

It sounds like you didn't just misspell it but rather specified something that's completely unparseable.  Could you show what it was that you misspelled? Our validation work will check that the name is at least well formed, but at this point I don't know what you've actually specified...

*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 75933 ***

(In reply to comment #2)
> It sounds like you didn't just misspell it but rather specified something
> that's completely unparseable.  Could you show what it was that you misspelled?
> Our validation work will check that the name is at least well formed, but at
> this point I don't know what you've actually specified...
> 
> *** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 75933 ***
> 

It took some time to reproduce it again, but eventually I found the cause. It is caused in the following scenario:

implements <!-- end-user-doc -->

in a class definition of a generated class (which is caused by bug 160145), which is not notified by the user (but ofcourse marked by the compiler). If the model is regenerated again from the genmodel, this errormessage will be produced. It is not caused by misspelling Instance Class Name.

Users (I ;)) should expect strange results when a process like this is done on faulty sources. But still, would it be something to consider popping a dialogbox on regenerating/merging sources with compilation errors, instead of this cryptic message?
We're also working on a AST based merger, so we can try to handle syntax errors during the merge process more gracefully as well...

traces.message: Unable to generate detailed source indexes
